snippet: The rapid expansion of hydraulic fracturing could put pressure on already-stressed water resources from the suburbs of Fort Worth to western Colorado, according to a new report from a nonprofit group.
abstract: Report from nonprofit group Ceres shows that rapid expansion of hydraulic fracturing to extract natural gas could further pressure water resources in parts of Texas and Colorado where water is already scarce.
lead_paragraph: The rapid expansion of hydraulic fracturing could put pressure on already-stressed water resources from the suburbs of Fort Worth to western Colorado, according to a new report from a nonprofit group.

headline.seo: Hydrofracking Could Strain Western Water Resources, Study Finds
headline.main: Spread of Hydrofracking Could Strain Water Resources in West, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Spread of Hydrofracking Could Strain Water Resources in West, Study Finds
